## Testing Rich HTML Output with gt

This document tests the new pseudoterminal implementation that captures rich HTML output without showing instrumentation code in the terminal.

### Install and Load gt

```{r}
if (!require("gt")) {
  install.packages("gt")
}
library(gt)
```

### Basic gt Table

```{r}
# Create a simple gt table
mtcars[1:5, 1:5] |>
  gt()
```

### Styled gt Table

```{r}
# Create a styled gt table with formatting
mtcars[1:8, ] |>
  gt(rownames_to_stub = TRUE) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Motor Trend Car Road Tests",
    subtitle = "A selection of cars from the 1974 Motor Trend US magazine"
  ) |>
  tab_stubhead(label = "Car Model")
```

### Styled gt Table with Colors

```{r}
# Create a styled gt table with column formatting
library(gt)
mtcars[1:6, 1:6] |>
  gt() |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Motor Trend Cars",
    subtitle = "Performance Metrics"
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_fill(color = "lightblue"),
    locations = cells_body(columns = mpg)
  )
```

### Testing Text Output Still Works

```{r}
# Regular text output should still work
summary(mtcars$mpg)
```

```{r}
# Data frame output
head(mtcars, 3)
```

### Mixed Output

```{r}
# Print text then create table
cat("Here's a table created with gt:\n")
iris[1:5, ] |> gt()
```
